comment: Purchased in southern Cali for 75$. Smooth, spicy, smokey, creamy, some mild sweetness. Water opened it up a little. Smells like oak, wood, maple, figs, some toffee.
Just purchased in OK for $54, can't wait to try it out
Awesome - smooth! Only other Orphan Barrel  that I've tried is Barterhouse and this is much better  in my opinion, a lot more complex. A good price performer at $70 - if you can find it.
Purchased in February 2015 from Sunset corners for $68.

Purchased today from a Total Wine store in NJ for $69. Very excited, already have the Barterhouse bottle. Will give it a try tomorrow. Stay Tuned.
Ok...tried it. Sensational.  I agree with another post here;  much better than the Barterhouse.  Could very well be my favorite to-date. Incredibly smooth, excellent finish.
Had in Alexandria, VA after Uncle Mikes funeral. $14/2oz. Damn good with a single ice cube.

Sweet nose, strong tasting notes of butterscotch, vanilla, caramel. A little floral on the palate.  Adding some water or an ice cube does wonders to bring out the favors and cool down the bite and bring out a more bolder, oaky, richer body. Not a smooth as I'd expect from something with this age statement but it still reminds me of an older Weller 12 year.
The reviews I read were dismissive, but I love it.
Best nose on a bourbon I've had. Smooth, complex, butterscotch awesomeness
Woodsy and suitably sweet for a bourbon. Excellent.
Big cinnamon, plum and burnt orange. Caramel apple and roasted walnuts followed by a crime brûlée finish.

Very woody.. Hence the name. Not old blow hard strong but woody. Decent bourbon, at the very least it tasted different than anything ive had. 

Not as rare as it was hyped to be. I got the lastbittle on the shelf. Within 7 months the shelf was full of them

Notes: bright fruit and citrus peel, oak, red licorice, berry, butterscotch  Taste: Oak, dark chocolate, leathery and toasted almond Finish: well balanced oaky slightly astringent with a drying quality

Woody and smooth.  Don't care where it came from; it tastes great.  Is it worth the price?  No.  Too thin and not complex enough. Tastes like average juice that was extra-aged.  I like to pair this with a smoked brisket.
Very very smooth with a buttery finish.
Has an ok flavor profile.  The price ranges a lot from place to place.  At the lower price points this isn't bad. At the higher price this is a skip.

Another lackluster effort from the Orphan Barrel series. There are two main problems. First, it's very thin. This would definitely benefit from a higher proof. Also, the flavor is very one note. All I get is vanilla. There is no depth of flavor, nothing, just vanilla. Luckily, I was able to get a pour in a bar and save some money.
Little too spicy for my taste on the front end. Has a nice smooth finish and an even nicer lingering aftertaste.
Purchased in TN for $67 along with Gifted Horse; yet to try this. GH was amazing
This one lacks the complexity / depth that I was looking for at the price point.  Overall, I will say it is pretty smooth, but mostly oaky in flavor.

He shoots, he scores!!
Robust vanilla and zing like Old Forester Birthday, not as sweet, better balance. Probably my favorite strong(er) vanilla selection yet. 
[Selanne Steak Tavern, 9th wedding anniv.]

Straight- spice and oak right up front, followed by a light sweet vanilla warm finish.
A few drops of water- sweet vanilla and oak, a lot of oak, nice warm finish
Full vanilla flavors. Very smooth. Very little aftertaste.
On the nose and palate, it's oaky spicy vanilla. Richness hangs around on the tongue.

This vanishing product is a descent 15 year and the name absolutely fits it's notes.  Nose of oak, wet wood, dried vanilla.  For me the oak is dominating the field.  body is light matching it's color which is surprising for a 15 year.  Palate of spices, peppers, Carmel.  It sweetens at the end in a very nice way.  The tannins from the wood come out.  I enjoyed this one, I wish the $65 price tag was a bit lower.  Keep drinking my friends... Skol!
Simple and smooth with a slight playfulness. Hard to identify a lot of the notes. Mellow sweetness that keeps reminding me of red hots.
I enjoyed it, but not worth the hype.  Luckily I only paid $65 in PA.
Strong overpowering oaky finish but still good
A serious helping of oak, the aroma is unique and overwhelming. The powerful tastes seems like it should be a higher proof. Not my favorite OB. 11.14.17 Columbus, OH
Lots of vanilla, a little heat and fruit.  Touches of acetone.  Flavor is definitely oak forward and overshadows some of the flavors.  Peppery finish.  Light, goes down quick.
Honey nose, palette is spicy and sweet with a peppery finish

The nose is waxy and mainly features the woody and vanilla scents of oak -- I almost wanted to shout, "Timber!" when drinking it.  The palate is not as complex as I'd hope for the age, with subtly sweet flavors, but first and foremost a bittersweet oak.  I had a hard time pinpointing or describing flavors, but I didn't find a lot of the typical caramel or fruit flavors of other bourbons.  The finish is well-rounded and mild:  banana nut muffins, spice, and oak.  The finish is the best part.  I've seen this bourbon for $90 and I've seen it for $150, and I wouldn't buy it at either price.

Last purchase at Kappy’s Fitchburg 12/28/2017

My notes:
Smooth, sipping wishkey. Woody with Carmel finish. Love it!

Well, after a week off from reviews while I was preparing for and performing at Tip Up Town USA (if you’re not familiar with it just google it),I’m back home recovering from the marathon weekend. I took an extra day off work to help the recovery and I decided to do a bourbon review. I got a sample of this 15 year old from Orphan Barrel from my Michigan bourbon buddy John. 

Bottled at a peculiar 45.25% ABV and a natural color of copper and I am guessing that it is chill filtered. 

The nose is dominated by cinnamon and clove. Plenty of oak as well with some light vanilla. Heavy corn influence, as is to be expected from the high proportion of corn in the mash bill. Mint and some light dill. Letting it sit a while reveals a nice toffee and caramel note with maple syrup. Somewhere in the background there is an orange-like citrus. Even though it’s a bit simplistic, there’s a nice nose to this bourbon. 

The palate, unfortunately goes the opposite direction. Sweet at first, but turns quite bitter. Very bitter dark chocolate, sharp oak and butterscotch. Pepper and cinnamon bring it to a close. 

A medium bodied mouthfeel that is slightly oily and dry. 
A medium long finish that is on the bitter side with cinnamon and oak. 

This is the third Orphan Barrel that I’ve tried, and I have to say that I haven’t really enjoyed any of them. I hate being overly critical of samples given to me by others, but over valuing them would be disingenuous. At $70 it’s not as expensive as the others I’ve had, but it’s still overpriced. I really did think the nose was good, similar to Buffalo Trace or Wild Turkey or a mix of the two, and that’s why it’s getting a 3 from me and not lower due to the overly bitter taste. Thanks for the sample John, even though I didn’t love it, it’s still fun to review whatever I can get my hands on. 
Cheers
lots of vanilla and Carmel. very easy drinking
Cherries, leather and dried fruit on the initial nose, vanilla and cherries on the palate then finishes with a huge oak punch.  Very tasty and super smooth!
True to its name! Tons of oak! Very smooth! Would recommend!

Nose - Oaky vanilla, cinnamon, mix of woods like you're in a lumber yard (mostly cedar/oak/maple/apple), hint of brown sugar.

Taste - Spicy cinnamon tingle & spice, sweet vanilla caramel, dark creme brulee sugar top, lightly tannic on the backend, sort of like a charred cinnamon stick.

Finish - Lingering tannic dryness, oaky vanilla simple, light cinnamon tingle mixed with a hotter white pepper tingle.

Score - 86/100

Final Thoughts - Interesting nose in that I get some other wood type notes other than oak along with the typical bourbon notes of cinnamon & vanilla. Not overly complex and surprisingly hot for the slightly lower proof. Good balance of oak and I don't think it was overly oaked/tannic but had enough to make it interesting. This is tasty but I'm not sure the price is justified.

Would I drink it if offered? - Yes

Would I specifically order it? - Maybe, if the price is right.

Would I buy a bottle? - No, I wouldn't pick up another.
Had one generous pour left in the bottle. Got to say I really enjoyed it. Sorry there is no more. Lots of vanilla and a hint of caramel. Loved it t the last drop...which I just did!
Smooth, oaky, short finish. Enjoyed neat.

I’ll have bourbons who live up to the hype for 100, Alex.

This bourbon smells delicious. I’m getting caramel apples. Body has a bit of cherry flavor mixed with sweet tea and caramel. Absurdly smooth and low heat, start to finish. Finish trails off with lemon zest and ginger.

There are times where this guy reminds me of the best parts of Russells Reserve. Times where it’s a Four Roses Limited from years back. Got some Wild Turkey 17 year in there. This genuinely is one of the more interesting bourbons I’ve had. 100% worth the money if you can find in on primary.
Amazing!  Definite campfire notes that are still lingering in my mind today.  Amazing, Amazing, Amazing

So as a rule I like to try these a few times before reviewing, but this one is just too tempting with it being a rare to find 15 year age stated bourbon.  So this is a bit more blind going in.  Bias going in, I'm expecting this to be underwhelming, somewhat poorly aged, and mostly a small step up from IW Harper 15 year (a disappointing all be it wonderful nosing bourbon).

Should also point out Stitzel Weller closed in 1992 meaning this would have had to have been in a steel vate since 2007, 12 years, for this to actually be 15 years old and from Stitzel Weller.  The story doesn't really checkout.  

Nose - vanilla, caramel, leather, finished dusty wood.  Very sweet, easily in the top quarter of sweet bourbon noses.  There's a lot of that dusty oak, really nice for us oak fans, but I can already tell this is going to be "over oaked" for many.  

Taste - Vanilla really is the story here.  The caramel notes from bourbon are well in the back ground as vanilla just bombards this one.  There is some bitter oak on the back, giving it a spice and bit of bite.  The 90ish proof is very soft and really only is noticed on the back end.  

Water really did nothing to the nose or taste - good or bad.  

Ok so verdict.  It's too light up front.  The sweetness from the nose doesn't come through here.  The oak adds a lot of spice which is going to upset a lot of people but for an oak fan, it doesn't add the more intense leathers or that cherry note I often get.  It is however clearly older whisky, it has some very nice sweet and middle of the road quality notes (middle of the road in the sense that it wasn't extreme in more shall we say "special" types of flavor such as super spicy rye notes or super sweet sugary notes).  

I come to for 30 bucks I can get Eight and Sand with a similar profile for 30 bucks and frankly that might be better bourbon.  

2 stars - if 100 bucks is well out of your normal purchase range, this should fall to 1 star for you.  It's a hard pass for all but those who want to try any and all older bourbons like myself.  I was debating going 2.25 or 2.5 due to my general appreciation of the age statement there are some quality all be it muted notes.
Underwhelming palate after an intriguing if not overly oaky nose. For this price point and age I expected more.  This one is a perfect example of “sometimes 15 year old whiskey is just old whiskey”.

Tastes like Halloween. This would be great to drink in the fall! Taste notes of sour apple and woody caramel. Notes smell like what the inside of a wooden cabin smells like. A bit of good black pepper. Also get the taste of the smell of what the inside of a plastic Halloween mask smells like... Tastes like the smell of dead leaves in the fall. If the Which’s Brew on Long Island served a whiskey, it would be this one. Overall 3/5. 4/5 if I were drinking this in the middle of autumn. Pick this up if you can get it on the cheap. Unique and would be excellent depending on the circumstances of drinking it.
Terrific bourbon. Perfect neat. Great story distillery.

Shiny bronze color. Honey, flowers and fruit on the nose. Tasting: oiliness, hotness, tannin finish. I'm feeling that the oak overwhelms everything else. I'm going to let it breath for a while and see how it goes.  It's helped other  high oak whiskies I've tried.
Very good, vanilla on the front, spicey bite on the back.
Rich and warm with a smokey end
Very Woody, more heat than Woodford but not unpleasant
Definitely flavorful with a lot going on, but got pretty strong hits of alcohol heat along the way. Worth trying at a bar
Smokey notes with hints of vanilla and Crème brûlée
Not bad but seems a little mild and simplistic for a 15 year old. A little boring
Smooth nice warmth opens up at the end for smooth finish.
Light carmel.  Warm finish.  Light and full flavor.  Light heat on nose
